Four types of fires A, B, C, D, (Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta). Alpha is anything that creates ash (including you), Bravo is liquids (petrol, oil, etc), Charlie is electrical, and Delta is metals (phosphorus road flares). So an A, B, C extinguisher should handle anything that you keep in your house including gasoline.

Im guessing the contents of the vase are AFFF (Aqueous Film Forming Foam). It works best where it can sit on a flat surface. The way this works is: steam from the evaporating water in it gets trapped by the rest of the liquid making foam. This causes it to flow out into a larger area. It is especially effective against burning liquids like gasoline, because the foam floats, covering the flammable liquid and preventing it from having access to oxygen in the air.

There is no class "ABC".

US fire classes:

Class A is typical solid fuel such as wood, paper, drywall, etc. An extinguisher for this class would be your standard CO2.
Class B is liquid fuel, such as gasoline or grease. Extinguishers for this class are PKP ("Purple-K", potassium bicarbonate), Monnex (potassium allophanate), or even soapy water. Smothering the fire, such as sliding a pan lid over a grease fire or other way of removing oxygen also works.
Class C is electrical. You turn off power to extinguish if it's small enough, but may turn into "A" if it spreads from the panel or device. May also use PKP to smother, do not use a liquid.
Class D is metal/chemical, such as magnesium or ammonium nitrate. DO NOT EVER USE WATER, it makes "D" fires worse. Ammonium nitrate is the major source behind the infamous Tianjin and Beirut explosions.
You don't put out class D fires, you let them burn out. If you're on a ship, dump the object overboard. It is possible to put out a chemical fire if you know exactly what is burning and how to break the chemical reaction, but chemical fires don't even need oxygen to burn, so the typical smothering or liquid approaches don't work.

Quick comments:
In the US, Class A is ordinary combustibles (wood, fabric, paper...), Class B is flammable liquids (gasoline, alcohol, paints...), Class C is electrical (electronics, wiring...). So if all three tested products were designed for ABC, they should all be able to handle even flammable liquids, contrary to what was mentioned.
Every fire extinguisher has a classification saying how big of a fire they can put out. Both the AFO and the vase were not designed to put out a fire like the pit used. The vase was designed to put out mostly flat fires (floor, doors, walls...). The AFO was designed to put out small semi-enclosed spaces (dumpster, cabinet...). Should they be tested on those fires they should work.
The portable fire extinguisher can put out a pit fire like this but it requires you to move around and hit it from multiple angles to reach all the faces of the wood inside. This was a problem of incorrect use.
I am a fire protection engineer and I can say that all of these products have their place but none will work outside of their specification. And all of them were designed for small INCIPIENT fires. A long burning fire pit is not incipient.
If you wish to re-do these tests with proper methods I would be glad to assist in the preparation.

The only type of fire that a CO2 extinguisher (and direct spray water, for that matter) is NOT used on is the Class D fire (burning metal such as magnesium) because of rapid cooling of the metal that will cause it to explode. A CO2 extinguisher works by eliminating oxygen and replacing it with carbon dioxide. You could do the same thing with just about any non-oxidizing gas (nitrogen, halon), but carbon dioxide is inexpensive and easy to store. A dry powder extinguisher can handle all four types of fires: combustible solids like wood or paper, combustible liquids like gasoline or grease, electrical, and metal fires. The idea behind a dry chemical fire extinguisher is to blanket the fuel with an inert solid (similar to dirt or sand). A dry chemical extinguisher sprays a very fine powder of sodium bicarbonate (baking soda), potassium bicarbonate (nearly identical to baking soda), or monoammonium phosphate. These solids coat the fuel and smother the fire. A CO2 extinguisher is much more efficient but more bulky. It's recognizable from the huge "horn" nozzle and no pressure gauge. Powder suppressant extinguishers have a way to test the inside ejection pressure.

Class A

Class A fires are fires in ordinary combustibles such as wood, paper, cloth, rubber, and many plastics.

￼

Class B

Class B fires are fires in flammable liquids such as gasoline, petroleum greases, tars, oils, oil-based paints, solvents, alcohols. Class B fires also include flammable gases such as propane and butane. Class B fires do not include fires involving cooking oils and grease.
￼

Class C

Class C fires are fires involving energized electical equipment such as computers, servers, motors, transformers, and appliances. Remove the power and the Class C fire becomes one of the other classes of fire.
￼

Class D

Class D fires are fires in combustible metals such as magnesium, titanium, zirconium, sodium, lithium, and potassium.
